cluster_relations.rel_desc: The black hole singularity lies at the center of and is a structural component of the black hole.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: once the black hole has formed
qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: at the center of the black hole
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: PhysicalNature: point of effectively infinite density and zero volume

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The event horizon is a structural boundary of the black hole.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: at the boundary of the black hole
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: beyond this boundary nothing can escape

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The traditional understanding of information storage is about how information is stored in the universe.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: traditional understanding of how information is stored

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Black holes contain a central singularity located at their center.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: at the center of a black hole

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Black holes are phenomena that exist within the universe.
The event horizon is the characteristic boundary surface of a black hole.
remarks: Uses domain knowledge slightly beyond explicit wording; kept with moderate confidence.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a structural part or boundary component of the object system or object.
args.justification: In all three cases, the subject (singularity or event horizon) is described as a structural element or boundary of a black hole; they share the same direction (component → whole) and semantics of structural part-of.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject system or object includes the object as one of its structural components.
args.justification: Here the direction is reversed (black holes → singularity) compared to the other part-of relations, so a complementary predicate is needed to capture whole → component while keeping consistent structural semantics.
All four relations describe how structural components (singularity, event horizon) and wholes (black hole) are related; they belong to the same family of structural part/whole and boundary relations.
These relations capture how complex objects are composed of structural parts and boundaries, which falls under a broad notion of compositional structure.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject phenomenon or entity exists or occurs within the spatial or cosmological domain denoted by the object.
args.justification: The description states that black holes are phenomena that exist within the universe; this is a standard existence-within-domain relation (phenomenon → containing universe).
This relation expresses where a phenomenon exists (black holes within the universe), grouping it with other existence-in-location or domain-of-existence predicates.
The key semantic dimension is that the phenomenon exists in a larger spatial/cosmological container (universe), which is best captured under SPATIALITY.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a theory, understanding, or concept has the object as its domain of applicability or scope.
args.justification: The relation describes the traditional understanding of information storage as being about how information is stored in the universe; this is a conceptual scope/applicability relation (understanding → universe), not mere containment.
This links a conceptual understanding to the domain it concerns (the universe), which fits a family of relations describing the scope or domain of applicability of concepts, models, or theories.
The relation is not about physical composition or location but about an abstract association of a concept with its domain of applicability; this fits best under a broad ASSOCIATION group.
